titleStmt.title: A Description of Dr Delany·s Villa.

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: by Dr. Sheridan.
Would you that Delville I describe,
Believe me Sir I will not gibe.
For Who woud be satirical
Upon a thing so very small.
You scarce upon the borders enter,
Before you're at the very center,
A single Crow can make it night,
When o'er your farm she takes her flight.
Yet in this narrow compass we,
Observe a great variety.
Both Walks, Walls, meadows, & parterres,
Windows, & doors, & Rooms & Stairs,
And hills, & dales, & woods & fields,
And hay, & grass, & Corn it yields,
All to your haggard brought so cheap in,
Without the mowing, or the Reaping,
A Razor tho to say it I am loth,
Woud shave you & your meadows both.
Tho small the farm, yet heres a House,
Full large to entertain a Mouse,
But where a Rat is dreaded more,
Than savage Caledonian Boar,
For if 'tis enterd by a Rat,
There is no room to bring a Cat.
A little Rivulet seems to steal,
Down thro a thing you call a Vale,
Like tears adown a wrinkled cheek,
Or rain a·long a blade of Leak,
And this you call your sweet meander,
Which might be suck·d up by a Gander,
Could he but force his nether bill,
To scoop the Channel of the rill,
I'm sure you·d make a mighty Clutter,
Where it as big as City gutter.
Next come I to your Kitchen garden,
Which one poor slug, woud fare but hard in,
And round this garden is a Walk,
No longer than a Taylors Chalk,
Thus I compute what space is in it,
A snail creep·s round it in a minute.
One Lettuce makes a shift to squeeze,
Up thro a tuft you call your Trees.
And once a year a single Rose,
Peep·s thro the bud, but never blows,
It cannot blow for want of Ro
In vain you may expect its Blo
In short, in all your boasted seat,
There's nothing but yourself is great.Y07B083Y
